description._content: "The building was erected in 1839, and is of solid stone. Convict labour undoubtedly, but the splendid nature of the undertaking, the mathematically correct angles of the walls, almost as smooth as brickwork, cannot but evoke admiration from even the most hypercritical spectator." - Frank Walker The building in question is now known as Rosedale, and is a prominent landmark in Little Hartley in the Blue Mountains. The building was originally licensed as the Coaches and Horses, but the name was changed to the Victoria inn at a later date. W.J. Berghofer acquired the building in 1903, where it was renamed Rosenthal, giving the origins of the modern day name for the mansion. The building is listed with the national trust. This image is part of a collection entitled ‘Early Australian Architecture', which is available to view on the Royal Australian Historical Society's Historypin Channel. Access the collection at the following link: www.historypin.com/channels/view/id/48441/#|collections/v... Please feel free to comment on this or any of the other images in the collection. If you have more accurate information regarding the location and/or date of the image, we would love to hear from you!
